  • 1.I.6E

    #Mathematical Biology
    2005

    Consider a biological system in which concentrations x(t)x(t)x(t) and y(t)y(t)y(t) satisfy

    dxdt=f(y)−x and dydt=g(x)−y\frac{d x}{d t}=f(y)-x \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{d y}{d t}=g(x)-y dtdx​=f(y)−x and dtdy​=g(x)−y

    where fff and ggg are positive and monotonically decreasing functions of their arguments, so that xxx represses the synthesis of yyy and vice versa.

    (a) Suppose the functions fff and ggg are bounded. Sketch the phase plane and explain why there is always at least one steady state. Show that if there is a steady state with

    ∂ln⁡f∂ln⁡y∂ln⁡g∂ln⁡x>1\frac{\partial \ln f}{\partial \ln y} \frac{\partial \ln g}{\partial \ln x}>1 ∂lny∂lnf​∂lnx∂lng​>1

    then the system is multistable.

    (b) If f=λ/(1+ym)f=\lambda /\left(1+y^{m}\right)f=λ/(1+ym) and g=λ/(1+xn)g=\lambda /\left(1+x^{n}\right)g=λ/(1+xn), where λ,m\lambda, mλ,m and nnn are positive constants, what values of mmm and nnn allow the system to display multistability for some value of λ\lambdaλ ?

    Can f=λ/ymf=\lambda / y^{m}f=λ/ym and g=λ/xng=\lambda / x^{n}g=λ/xn generate multistability? Explain your answer carefully.

  • 3.II.13E

    #Mathematical Biology
    2005

    Protein synthesis by RNA can be represented by the stochastic system

    x1⟶λ1x1+1 and x1⟶β1x1x1−1x2⟶λ2x1x2+1 and x2⟶β2x2x2−1\begin{array}{lll} x_{1} \stackrel{\lambda_{1}}{\longrightarrow} x_{1}+1 & \text { and } & x_{1} \stackrel{\beta_{1} x_{1}}{\longrightarrow} x_{1}-1 \\ x_{2} \stackrel{\lambda_{2} x_{1}}{\longrightarrow} x_{2}+1 & \text { and } & x_{2} \stackrel{\beta_{2} x_{2}}{\longrightarrow} x_{2}-1 \end{array}x1​⟶λ1​​x1​+1x2​⟶λ2​x1​​x2​+1​ and  and ​x1​⟶β1​x1​​x1​−1x2​⟶β2​x2​​x2​−1​

    in which x1x_{1}x1​ is an environmental variable corresponding to the number of RNA molecules per cell and x2x_{2}x2​ is a system variable, with birth rate proportional to x1x_{1}x1​, corresponding to the number of protein molecules.

    (a) Use the normalized stationary Fluctuation-Dissipation Theorem (FDT) to calculate the (exact) normalized stationary variances η11=σ12/<x1>2\eta_{11}=\sigma_{1}^{2} /<x_{1}>^{2}η11​=σ12​/<x1​>2 and η22=\eta_{22}=η22​= σ22/<x2>2\sigma_{2}^{2} /<x_{2}>^{2}σ22​/<x2​>2 in terms of the averages <x1><x_{1}><x1​> and <x2><x_{2}><x2​>.

    (b) Separate η22\eta_{22}η22​ into an intrinsic and an extrinsic term by considering the limits when x1x_{1}x1​ does not fluctuate (intrinsic), and when x2x_{2}x2​ responds deterministically to changes in x1x_{1}x1​ (extrinsic). Explain how the extrinsic term represents the magnitude of environmental fluctuations and time-averaging.

    (c) Assume now that the birth rate of x2x_{2}x2​ is changed from the "constitutive" mechanism λ2x1\lambda_{2} x_{1}λ2​x1​ in (1) to a "negative feedback" mechanism λ2x1f(x2)\lambda_{2} x_{1} f\left(x_{2}\right)λ2​x1​f(x2​), where fff is a monotonically decreasing function of x2x_{2}x2​. Use the stationary FDT to approximate η22\eta_{22}η22​ in terms of h=∣∂ln⁡f/∂ln⁡x2∣h=\left|\partial \ln f / \partial \ln x_{2}\right|h=∣∂lnf/∂lnx2​∣. Apply your answer to the case f(x2)=k/x2f\left(x_{2}\right)=k / x_{2}f(x2​)=k/x2​.

    [Hint: To reduce the algebra introduce the elasticity H22=∂ln⁡(R2−/R2+)/∂ln⁡x2H_{22}=\partial \ln \left(R_{2}^{-} / R_{2}^{+}\right) / \partial \ln x_{2}H22​=∂ln(R2−​/R2+​)/∂lnx2​, where R2−R_{2}^{-}R2−​and R2+R_{2}^{+}R2+​are the death and birth rates of x2x_{2}x2​ respectively.]

    (d) Explain the extrinsic term for the negative feedback system in terms of environmental fluctuations, time-averaging, and static susceptibility.

    (e) Explain why the FDT is exact for the constitutive system but approximate for the feedback system. When, generally speaking, does the FDT approximation work well?

    (f) Consider the following three experimental observations: (i) Large changes in λ2\lambda_{2}λ2​ have no effect on η22\eta_{22}η22​; (ii) When x2x_{2}x2​ is perturbed by 1%1 \%1% from its stationary average, perturbations are corrected more rapidly in the feedback system than in the constitutive system; (iii) The feedback system displays lower values η22\eta_{22}η22​ than the constitutive system.

    What does (i) imply about the relative importance of the noise terms? Can (ii) be directly explained by (iii), i.e., does rapid adjustment reduce noise? Justify your answers.

    A chemostat is a well-mixed tank of given volume V0V_{0}V0​ that contains water in which lives a population N(t)N(t)N(t) of bacteria that consume nutrient whose concentration is C(t)C(t)C(t) per unit volume.     K(C)=Kmax⁡CK0+CK(C)=\frac{K_{\max } C}{K_{0}+C} K(C)=K0​+CKmax​C​

    and the bacterial population grows at a rate γNK(C)\gamma N K(C)γNK(C), where 0<γ<10<\gamma<10<γ<1.

    Write down the differential equations for N(t),C(t)N(t), C(t)N(t),C(t) and show that they can be rescaled into the following form:
